Review: Against the Storm really shows its strength in when you pause the game. In most RTS games, you pause to manage micro. That's absolutely something you can do in Against the Storm, but the micro isn't really very punishing, so you're not going to gain much efficiency doing that versus managing in real time. The challenge in Against the Storm, and why you pause, is choosing which direction you're going to move your economy. The game actually pauses itself when giving certain choices. There are a lot of effects which can modify the game, making certain actions more or less rewarding. Ultimately, your goal is to make a functional system providing for the needs of your town for long enough to move on, which involves balancing exploitation and sustainability, and pushing your economy into a direction where beneficial effects cause it to be far more efficient than a basic one. Like most RTS, Against the Storm is a race against the clock, but what really matters is the making it through the hostile storms which close each year, when a host of negative effects make managing your settlement more difficult, most significantly by causing your townspeople to lose hope. The game is tuned so that providing for your people and making it through these storms become progressively more difficult as your settlement expands and time goes by. People leave when they are fed up, making the town simultaneously easier to provide for while also subtracting from the timer you have before you are hauled back from leadership, presumably to be dressed down by the throne. The metagame around the basic gameplay is also rich, with rewards scaling with difficulty, a prestige system that makes it progressively harder, and a quest to reforge seals which rewards you for finishing settlements in fewer years. All-in-all, I'm very pleased with the game, and have not climbed near the top of it yet despite over a hundred hours and dozens of settlements.

The Signifier suffers from the negative impact of a fairly common trend in videogame: simplification of interface. Much of the game takes place in a reconstructed mindscape, with odd distortions and glitched voxel blitting. It's an environment where figuring out how to interact is not always straightforward, a problem the devs attempt to resolve in two ways, making a system of in-game rules for interactions, and restricting the level of interaction allowed. The rules system works, more or less, but the restriction on interactions is not uniform enough. When you're not allowed to pick the average object up, or move in certain ways that are only slightly visually counterindicated, it's not always clear what you are allowed to do. Sometimes merely looking at something is enough to trigger the quicktime event advancing the plot, sometimes you have to click an eye or hand icon, which isn't always immediately visible. There's a reason that the VR version is so hotly anticipated, as it would potentially fix much of this interaction problem, but, also, probably a reason why it's not forthcoming, as making it would likely require nontrivial interaction fixes.

Space exploration is made possible through the tireless efforts of scientists. It's about getting to mind-boggling velocities and designing systems that function in vacuum. It's not, generally, all that predictable or easy to understand. Mars Horizon puts you at the head of a space agency, and sweeps all the technical detail under the rug. Progress in Mars Horizon is made through missions, where you launch a module into space and have it perform certain actions. The minigame here has potential, but is hampered by the fact that the actions and effects are almost completely decoupled from the real thing. You're managing several different bins of resources; starting with 'energy', you need to create 'communications', 'data', 'navigation', etc. This in itself is fine, but the actions you're using to manipulate them and the motivations for their critical success and failure are all technobabble. Some of the special resources, like 'alignment', 'heat'. and 'thrust', do a better job of tying into the actual reality of the missions, but that's the exception and not the rule. Most egregious, in my opinion, was the energy mechanism where, if you didn't like the result of an action, you could "force" it for 1 energy. This felt very cheap, as when something actually goes wrong on a mission like that, throwing energy at it won't help. As a result, I found that I wasn't able to be as immersed in the missions as I wanted. Most of the rest of the game is a turn-based management sim, competing with your rival space agencies to be the first to various preset mission objectives. There's also a diplomacy system, but interactions with other agencies feel distant and limited. Mostly, you're trying to make sure you spend your money wisely enough that you can keep your space program running. A large part of your early game is worrying about finding room for all the buildings your space agency wants at your 'base', which, for some reason, you decided to build in a hilly and heavily wooded area. Chopping down those trees and leveling that land will cost money! And don't forget the adjacency bonuses for placing different building types next to each other, something which I couldn't find any explanation of beyond the red and green lines that appear when you go to attempt to place the buildings next to each other! All in all, I quit sometime around the manned mission to the moon, because I felt more like a rocket parts and facilities accountant than a space explorer. It's too bad, because I really wanted to like this game. It has decently modeled renditions of actual historical rocket stages, and interesting blurbs which pop up when you complete missions and research (cynically, probably only as a condition of the support of the ESA). Something which could have been an interesting educational experience by more closely integrating actual history, a more engaging experience by sticking closer to the actual mechanics of spaceflight, or a funner experience by increasing the potential for interaction between agencies and making the game multiplayer, instead turns into a single-player slog.
So melodramatic.

Beyond: Two Souls is an interesting concept that ends up being underwhelming in execution. The first thing you might notice starting the game is the quality of the face models, which is very high. Unfortunately, the rest of the game doesn't continue to deliver on that quality. On the same topic, the face rigging is not quite good enough, so many expressions end up looking a bit wooden, but there are also large shortfalls in writing and gameplay. Gameplay Gameplay in Two Souls is often as interesting and engaging as using a remote to change the television channel, if you weren't quite sure which button you needed to press to change it. The core gameplay centers around walking, basic object interaction, and quicktime events, with occasional dialogue choices. The walking and interaction portion is fairly restrictive, with obtrusive methods to keep players on the rails, while also sometimes failing to indicate how to progress. Because certain actions, like walking out of a given area, or interacting with plot irrelevant objects, end up being categorically disallowed, it's easy to assume that certain choices and actions will be disallowed if they aren't obviously presented. Additionally, it's far too easy to end up stuck on objects, and the walking pace rarely varies, even when a run would be more narratively appropriate. At one of the few points you do run, it immediately bugged and got the character caught in a wall. Seeing your character doing a walk cycle stuck to the corner of a table is funny, but breaks immersion as much as the game's guardrails. Quicktime events I recognize as a neccessary evil to provide people who aren't very good at gaming a way to feel immersed and triumphant in gameplay. However, those in Beyond: Two Souls, suffer from often having the cues for directional reactions be unclear. Writing The writing ended up failing for me on two levels. While the overall storyline was OK, the writing was constantly melodramatic, making many narrative decisions to maximize drama instead of provide explanation or background. The path through the work was very linear, and I even got dialogue that blatantly contradicted choices I'd made earlier. At a very basic level, a canon and continuity for the story was lacking. The power and ability of the spirit you control seems driven purely by narrative convenience, as do many of the details of the game world. In the end, it gives the game the same level of narrative quality as a bad movie; entertaining in the moment but cheesy and easily forgettable. P.S. Where it went wrong Beyond: Two Souls does include some information about development, unlocked by collecting certain 'Bonuses' as Aiden. I didn't unlock all of them, but here's what I noticed from those I did unlock: - Quantic Dream had good concepts. I unlocked two trailers for games 'not currently under production', and found them at least as interesting as Two Souls itself. - I was surprised to learn that the game was done almost entirely using motion capture. The rigidness of the facial models at points and the derpy walk cycles indicate that Quantic Dream didn't adequately invest in the algorithms or QA necessary for translating their capture into the game world, despite enormous investment in the capture itself. - The creative team was run as a dictatorship with a scriptwriter on the top, and knowing this makes it unsurprising that the writing is often anemic and many player decisions are on rails. In the interview about gameplay David Cage states that he has "an idea of how [he] wants the story to be played". That's followed by a quote by Associate Lead Gamplay developer Simon Wasselin, who states that they developed the game constantly checking "to see if it matches what he had in mind. In case it doesn't we go back to the writing stage and keep working until it perfectly matches David's vision." This is an unhealthy way to run a creative team. A competent creator knows how to take criticism, collaborate, and adapt to the medium, skills that would be difficult to hone or display in such an environment.

Review: Let's be clear: "5D Chess With Multiverse Time Travel" is a really good idea. I recommend it wholeheartedly with the following provisos. 1. It's not really 5D Chess. There are at most 4 dimensions in evidence: The 2D chess board repeated in time and multiverse dimensions. With the title, I expected that time travel would be in addition to 5 full dimensions. 2. The rules around time+multiverse travel are a bit dicey. Whether you like it or not, chess itself is a very polished game. It's well balanced and still, allowing for a few special cases, very easy to grasp. In contrast, the multiverse portion of the game feels very much like the first version that ended up even remotely balanced. Things like the somewhat arbitrary restriction on number of active boards or the importance of multiverse ordering add obscurity to the game, while the somewhat flat extension of piece moves into the additional dimensions mean that the pieces' abilities in these dimensions don't end up very balanced. Pawns are near worthless, while knights, due to their unique ability to move freely through the multiverse, far more powerful. The developer attempted to address these shortcomings by introducing two new pieces to the game; the dragon and the unicorn, which essentially act like multiverse-native variations on bishops, but this barely scratches the surface of what should be possible in more dimensions. 3. The playerbase is small. Frankly, the above problems are forgivable because there is an active playerbase good at the game. It is still quite small, and, as far as I know, localized to the game's Discord server. All in all, good for a meme, and will get you thinking about multidimensional possibilities. EDIT: Played a bit more, had a decent public match even. Balance issues persist and one of the setups 'Misc - Very Small' is Mate-in-1. Better than chess, but not by too much. Again, negative review very much a reflection of the anemic playerbase. EDIT: Joining the Discord server has solved my main gripe with this game. Changed review to be positive.

Very clever game about building a character and strategy around a coin bag. When you loot chests, you choose a certain number of coins from a selection with different powers and values to add to your bag. In battle, you get a set of coins randomly drawn from your bag each turn, and have to choose to use them, redraw, or simply wait. There's very little to gameplay beyond your battles with enemies and looting chests; the game makes it interesting with a wide variety of coins and enemies. It's a roguelike, so you have to enjoy some grinding while you work out some broader strategy. Absolutely playable without the DLC, but the DLC is also one of the few game additions I've never had second thoughts about purchasing.

Review: There's clearly a good deal thought and effort put into Caster, but still not *enough* thought or effort. Caster has the bare bones of a good game: nice powers, an engaging storyline, an engrossing world... the problem is that all of these are incomplete. The powers are not balanced or tuned to the levels. The storyline lacks writing. You only get claustrophobic glimpses of the world, with very little indication that there's more in the distance. Not worth the hype. :/ As someone who's played and enjoyed many other games in similar genres, I was excited to play Darkest Dungeon, but found that it didn't hold up in comparison to the others I'd played. The most obvious game to compare this to is Monster's Den: Book of Dread. Monster's Den is a free turn based game from 2008 where you explore a dungeon and fight enemies for rewards. There's no town, but the combat is incredibly nuanced and rewarding. Compared to this, Darkest Dungeon combat felt repetitive and clunky. The equip system was also not nearly as harrowing. There's generally only one or two characters where their equips will even *work*, so you don't need to worry about who gets the rare shoes and who gets cloth stockings. Still, there's something to be said for simplicity. The modern XCOM games abstract a lot of your choices, leaving you with a 2D movement system and a few variations on 'fire', and are still formidable chance-based strategy. Darkest Dungeons is essentially the same thing, only with 1D movement. The problem is that 1D movement is a lot more constrained than 2D. There are only 4 positions in every battle, and players mostly stand in the same place to keep their attacks effective. This leaves just management (torches, looting, town) and attacks as the deep mechanics. One of the most powerful draws of Darkest Dungeon is the 'roguelike progress', which invites you to feel like you're moving forward, even as heroes crumple at your feet. Adding story-style progress to a roguelike is a difficult yet emotionally powerful mechanic that's difficult to do right. Darkest Dungeon uses a RPG-style checklist as well as town management mechanics to motivate this. It's effective, but not an elegant solution, and you're prone to feeling sometimes that you're just slogging through dark halls, as opposed to participating in a story. Another draw is the art style. Even if the mechanics of a game aren't as well oiled as they could be, that can all be made up for by a slick visual style. I have to admit that I don't know anything quite as striking as the stress and victory halos the heroes get as they fail and succeed. Still, it's not as if this game is unique in that right either. As a top-down shooter, Our Darker Purpose is a bit different gameplaywise, but it still does far better at motivating 'roguelike progress', and equally good at putting out a visual style to make you question the dark nature of humanity. In conclusion, if you look at Darkest Dungeon and say "a Cthulian-style roguelike management game? That's just what I've *needed*", purchase it, you won't be disappointed. If you're like me and say "Darkest Dungeon? I've heard good things about it, so it must be really great", then I'd recommend you think twice. There's not much here that hasn't been done better elsewhere.

This is often difficult for roguelikes to achieve, but Our Darker Purpose does an admirable job with its lore and achievement system. -Strong sense of progression. Again, the achievement system, along with a credit system and a chapter progression, combine to make you seem like you're moving forward even if you're dying over and over. Weaknesses: -Non-procedural generation. There are only so many rooms that spawn. Aside from the somewhat klutzy feel of the hitboxes in the game, some interactions don't work as explained or intended (I'm looking at you, the 6 people you meet in Edgewood).

Review: As I made my way through the 300 years it takes to charge the chalice, I was originally planning to write a cautious positive review. This game deserves some praise for the solid mechanics it demonstrates. They make the game fun, even through plodding self-insert writing, repetitive gameplay, and general lack of refinement in several aspects of the game. I'd planned to say that the game was good, and would have been great, if only polished more. Unfortunately, after finishing, I find myself unable to give this recommendation. For context, everything in the game builds towards the charging of the chalice. You send crack teams of five controllable heros out to occasional battles, and decide the research, intercourse and economy of an upper class of those 'attuned to the chalice' in a nation beset by a sinister enemy, the Cadence. The rest of the time, you 'sleep'. The game builds the chalice as a mystical power, with dialogue-based time shenanigans and curative powers that spice up the 300 year wait. These 3 choice dialogues were actually a very necessary respite for the tedium of waiting 300 years, going through battles that because of the mildly varied but still quite limited classes and locations soon became a bit repetitive. So naturally, I expected something special for the final battle. Perhaps being able to use all of my heros in an epic final stand, or, going off the time shenanigans earlier, being able to choose my heros from all of those who'd passed away as well as those alive. So, I was somewhat disappointed that the selection was made normally. It turned out that there actually was something different about the final battle, the enemy attempted to attack the 500HP chalice instead of your heros, something that actually made it easier. Oh well, I'd been playing on normal, so perhaps it would have been more epic on greater difficulty. Dispatch the last of the enemies and... done! Only, the ending was a disappointment. A flop on the visual, emotional, and writing level. Not much worse than the starting cutscene, but after 300 years... you expect something a bit more. Drama, a last look at your kingdom, something. There *was* a grand reveal, but so hamhanded that it had very little impact, and didn't make the half-day that playing the game through takes worthwhile. So I retried the game on brutal hardcore difficulty, though it's worth noting that I never restored from save on my first game. Long story short, my heart was no longer in it. The whole game builds toward the end, and since I now knew that was no great shakes, it was just a slog. I made it maybe 50 years before my alchemists blew up, and even though I very well might persist, I no longer felt it. TL;DR Brilliant idea, but disappointing.

Review: It's an awesome story. Pros: -Excellent Story showcasing escape from 3 law robotics -Excellently realized alien creatures -Quality, heartfelt writing Unfortunately, I can't really recommend this as a game. Just based on the story this game would be boss, if it was reasonably playable without a walkthrough. It's not. Cons: -Terrible UI -Puzzles often don't give hints, and actions equivalent from human perpective are not game equivalent -Overdependence on quicktime events ruins sandbox feel. You play as A.R.I.D., a military suit A.I. concerned with the health of her occupant. A.R.I.D. is of near-human intelligence, perhaps on the upper bound of it. You interact with the environment via a series of magnifying glass indicators illuminated by flashlight which allow you to see a short description, and interact directly, through network interface, or via items you've picked up (or are nearby). This actually makes a fairly good concept. Illuminating the items adds atmosphere and helps make you feel as though it's you interacting with the objects, even though the relevant animations are automated. Unfortunately, as soon as you have a working sidearm, you toggle between flashlight and laser sight, and laser sight doesn't allow you to interact at all, something I found to be a bit silly, since it still provided a fair amount of illumination. Additionally the 'interact with objects nearby' function isn't well explained, and is only used twice, so it seems grafted on. Another thing that's only used a couple times is the networking function, a top level option on your interact menu. I feel it would make the game richer if the devs had taken the time to add some bits of useless information which you could also grab with your networking capabilities. More detrimental to the gameplay is the 'one path' approach to puzzles. A lot of things seem human equivalent, and should be clear to A.R.I.D. too, given her intelligence. I shouldn't have to distinguish between the source of the fluid and fall of the fluid when collecting it; when I need stuff from something on the ground I can't pick up, what I do need in order to extract it should be made obvious. Given the size of the puzzles, too, there should be a bit more guidance around answers that are almost, but not quite correct. I can hardly count the number of times I saw 'I can't do that.' when I was this close to a solution. The most irritating thing, from a narritive perspective, was the game's assumption that certain events happened in some sort of sequence. A lot of the text I read referred to objects as 'more' or 'another' when I had never even seen one, and the way I traversed the levels triggered the storyline events erratically, one too early, another too late, making the story itself less satisfying. Also, I glitched into a wall during the boss fight. All in all, I find that it's better if I think of this as a sedately paced interactive story with some action than as a game. I actually feel it would be better to remove some of the gameplay than to allow the loose ends and unpredictibiliy such elements leave to interfere with the story. Better still would be to manage such unpredictibility, but the designers don't seem to have done that very well.

PAYDAY 2 used to be a decent game. Something to boot with a couple of friends and spend 15 minutes yelling at each other because one of you tripped the alarm, the other keeps dying, and the third has taken the loot to the polar opposite of the dropoff zone, where they're being overwhelmed by heavy police presence. Overkill may have gone, well, overkill with some of the DLC, but they were adding new content to the game, even if it tended to bit a bit pricey. Then, October 16th, 2015, there was a new addition to the game. Or... calling it an addition is far too generous. There was, all of a sudden, a new crate drop system. Now, before I continue, let me say that I am not actually opposed to the idea of such a system, putting aside the fact that Overkill had, up until this point, all but explicitly promised not to make any microtransaction system part of the game. TF2 has a crate drop system that I must have spent ~$100 on, at this point. That's fine. You can get everything you need to play the game from free weapon drops, and the crate system serves solely to make available more cosmetic functions, and support a free game. Coincidentally, ~$100 is also the amount spent so far for my PAYDAY game and DLC acquisition. In the Payday 2 the crates (safes) carry skins. Skins... that's not much content-wise, that should be entirely ancillary to the gameplay! Or so I hear the logical, rational portion of my brain shout. You really shouldn't criticize Overkill for adding something new to the game, or well, for trying to. Even if they did manage to break all of the game's mods, up to and including HoxHud. It's the thought that counts. Or perhaps it's your wallet. Because if you look closer, take a key (drill) to your crate (safe), you will find that each skin corresponds with a stat boost. If you try to play the game, you will find that the safe-dropping update coincides with a nerf to nearly every reasonably playable gun. That nerf makes them all but unplayable without... a stat boost. All of a sudden things look a lot less funny. In order to play the same game you may have spent in the ballpark of $100 on, you now need to: -Unlock a safe with a drill (and be out the money or time it took to do so) -Hope to get a skin for a weapon you own -Hope the skin has good stats that bring the weapon on par with where it was before the update -Hope the skin doesn't look ugly as hell That's a lot of hoping/money/playtime/etc. The take-home: dropping safes on people is a classic gag, but it's not so funny when it happens to you. Kind of strikes you as... Overkill, really.

:( First, let me preface this review by saying that Zeno Clash is just about the best thing ever. I was going to write a rave review about it, but I foolishly decided to play Zeno Clash 2 first. The problems start with the tutorial/prelude. I might not have played the tutorial if it hadn't also been labelled prelude. As it was, punching Metamoq in the face with some voiceover recap of the plot of the previous Zeno Clash in the background sounded like just the thing, which should indicate how good the first Zeno Clash was. The first thing I noticed was the lack of filters. The first Zeno Clash had a hazy effect, which made distant objects blur and added to the atmosphere, and which I assumed was an attribute of Zenozoik. Not so, apparently, since that effect is gone in this game. Instead there is music added to the voiceover. Music was used sparingly in the first Zeno Clash, so the overall effect was that of excessive melodrama. Oh well, if a bit overdone, the plot is still awesome, and punching Metamoq in the face till it's over should be simple, right? After all, I defeated the last game, and know how this goes. ... Not so much. It turns out that there's combos and stuff now. The 'lock on' key has been switched, which is a minor annoyance, but more annoying is that it's a bit difficult to connect with some of the attacks. I find out that the tutorial is glitched when I manage to check a box without fulfilling the requirements, and just stand there for a while, since the game won't move forward until I satisfy the /actual/ requirements. It's here that I start to worry that the game might be overcome by feature creep. A worry which is not abated when I find that, despite beating the previous game, I am unable to do the '5-part launch combo' required in the tutorial, even more ironic since it comes after Metamoq's quote: "If you are satisfied and do what you feel you must do, no matter what that is, then you have reached perfection." Apprehensive, I finally quit from the endless nightmare of facing a downcast Metamoq and start the real game, hopeful that the tutorial was an ill-conceived quick add-on. But of course, the problems continue into the real game. The combat system is now so complex that I have no idea what I'm doing in the first fight, and the AI manages to trip over itself without any clever guidance from me. In the first game, if you plan it right, you can have heavy enemies smash through lighter ones to get to you, or have lighter ones glare at you, unable to attack through the enemy interposed between you. You can even attack enemies from behind if they're distracted by picking up weapons, something which I had to exploit to defeat one scene. But the AI in the first game is actually pretty good. It hides from your shooting range when it thinks it can, and does stuff like sneak up behind you. I didn't see any of that here. What I did see wasn't much better. Somehow, combat looks jittery, and the lighting isn't the same. I saw a new creature design, with even more nudity, and knocked it out before stumbling across a most egregious example of feature creep. Remember how the 'lock on' key was remapped? It's now the key for 'exit area'. To understand how terrible this is, you have to understand how the first Zeno Clash worked. You would sometimes walk places without fighting, and sometimes you would fight. Another example of Metamoq's wisdom. Oh well, I exit, and the story goes on... and on. One of the great strengths of the first Zeno Clash was how much it did with very little dialogue. This is not the case here, where it takes three sentences for your sister to tell you that you're helping her break Father-Mother out of jail. And then... nothing. Oh wait, a tower that says 'Level Up!'. Feature creep indeed! Let's go there, then get stuck before realizing that we have no skill points yet, pull out a map, which utterly butchers the charming minimalism of the one in the first Zeno Clash, then forget how to put it away, leaving us stuck, until we remember it was 'M', and run around aimlessly, and... we can talk to a person? Wait a sec, did we just get a quest? When did this become an RPG, anyway? Not the first Zeno Clash, not a good RPG. (-10)/10

It's really unfortunate that I can't give this game a good review... it's got some very nice attention to detail at some points, such as when you try to boost Erica, the protagonist, into her cognition mode when she's already there. You get an artfully done flash of red, indicating a rush of blood at the fruitless attempt to boost her preternatural ability. Or take Erica's mobile phone, where you can do anything from choose tags for web searches for entertainment, to have Erica tell you that she doesn't happen to feel like listening to music at the moment , as her brother is currently being tortured. When you break the hand off a statue, in an act of possibly regrettable vandalism, the hand stays behind, instead of disappearing into hammerspace . Details like these can really make a game experience, providing immersion for some truly diverting story or gameplay. And this is where the game fails. The gameplay is fairly standard for a point-and-click, with a nice flourish from the cognition ability and the very streamlined interaction system, so that's not the problem... No, the game fails on story. The first puzzle turns out to be very simple, something easy to solve while you're still leaning the interface. The madman who has taken Erica's brother has used a makeshift lock to hide in a masoleum, then buried the key out back. Without waiting for backup, Erica and her partner bust into the graveyard , where the only shovel has been cemented into the hand of the 'weeping angel'-style statue . It's a point-and-click, so instead of being able to dig in the loose dirt with her hands, Erica needs to use the hammer from the toolbox to whack off the statue's hand, in order to obtain the shovel to dig. Fine. Except Erica can't dig. The shovel is tainted with the psychic unpleasantness of having whacked her brother in the back of the head . She tries, then tearfully informs the player that she can't use the shovel. An entirely psychic weakness from a psychic isn't very reassuring, and it's conveyed to be on about the same level as a fear of spiders, which is puzzling. It's one of my pet peeves in these sorts of games when the character refuses to do something; not because they couldn't, or it isn't really feasible, but just because they don't want to get their hands dirty. It's a tendency which disproportionately affects female characters. Okay, fine. Maybe I'm being unfair. After all, it's not like psychic abilities don't have downsides too. A blessing and a curse. In any case, Erica goes back to get her male partner and tells him to dig, which he ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ about, but he probably doesn't know about her ability. A secret, double-edged ability, wielded gingerly by a ginger heroine. At this point, I feel like I may have been a bit unfair to label the exchange unreasonably sexist. Erica claims the key from the ground and heads to the front of the masoleum. Then things get really bad. First of all, in the upcoming exchange, her partner reveals that he knows about Erica's ability, which ruins my headcanon of Erica's careful management of her secret capability. Then again, the entire scene ruins Erica's credibility, and calls into question her ability to reasonably manage anything. Erica trys the arcane stone wheel key on the makeshift lock, and tries to turn it. It won't turn, not unless someone is standing on the pressure plate. 'It's a trap!' says her partner, fat white male police guy, 'wait for backup!'. 'No!' snarls Erica, 'I'm doing this'. She turns the wheel... and spikes pop out near her legs. 'Stop!' says fat white police guy 'You see, I was right!' (Actually, I think I jumped the gun on his previous line of dialogue, so he doesn't actually say this, he says that instead, but w/e). And then Erica pulls her gun and points it at her partner's head. Erica has an FBI badge in her inventory, and my guess is that it isn't forged. Given that, her pulling of a gun loses all its melodramatic teenager-style charm. Erica should know how to use a gun , and would only pull it in two cases, to incapacitate, aiming at limbs to slow a dangerous target, or to kill, as a last resort. Given how her gun is directed, she's offering to kill her partner for worrying about her safety. Just wait, it gets worse. Turns out the cryptic message scrawled on the door indicates that the murderer who has her brother wants her to drive the spikes into her shins by continuing to turn the wheel. He's watching them through the camera he installed, so he could probably open the door at any time. Erica's plan is... to do it. Her resolution here is utterly baffling after her refusal to lift a shovel . She turns the wheel to do so, and gives a shriek indicating low pain-tolerance, even after being totally prepared (if I was being sexist, I would say the shriek was 'manly', due to some studies which indicate that men have, on average, lower pain tolerances. Not everyone bases their sexism on statistically derived fact, however, so I feel that the majority of people would come to the opposite determination, were they being sexist). The door opens, and... the trap springs! Catching her partner in the chest, which Erica seems not too unhappy about. She slumps down the stairs, having difficulty walking on her wounded yet not overly bloody legs, making attractive poses against the walls of the spiral staircase. At this point, I could only come to the determination that the developers were of a sadomasochistic bent, who apart from that (in and of itself, not so shameful) likely enjoyed writing a female character due to all the irrational decisions they could justify with one (which is definately a shame). Erica is supposed to be an FBI agent, something which takes no small amount of work and competance. Instead, she's written like a troubled teenager, which utterly kills the story.

Game: BIT.TRIP Presents... Runner2: Future Legend of Rhythm Alien
Review: I'm not quite sure what I expected before I played Runner2, probably another obstacle course with the same clear-cut pixel graphics and simple charm of the prequel Runner, perhaps with a bit more underlying menace or excitement pursuant to a Rhythm Alien which apparently featured in it. What I got was something with the same basic gameplay, but with a lot of extras. Extras? Extras are good, right? If you played the first Runner, there was almost nothing more satifying than getting an extra, then speeding along with the music at full audibility, collecting gold with a rainbow contrail stretching to infinity. Sadly though, in this version, extras result in a watery rainbow which trails sadly in your wake, and the music doesn't really noticably change throughout the course of a level. I suppose that anything less wouldn't fit the new 'style' of the game. No, these extras are the normal sort of game extras, extra characters and collectable outfits and a 'reward' system. Collectible outfits? If you're still thinking of the first BIT.TRIP Runner, you may be wondering how that works. I could tell you the first outfit was a pair of earbuds, and you might wonder if that meant whitining a couple pixels on the Runner's ears. Not to fear though, it's all part of the new 'style'. At the beginning of the game, a smarmy narrator informs you that CommanderVideo has been sucked into an alternate dimension, while fighting in some manner of justice league. A new world awaits, with a lot more living things, and more importantly, real 3D graphics. I don't feel that 3D graphics really do much for the game. I felt that my runner was not a s responsive due to the slower nature of the jump animation. In fact, starting out, the overhangs on staircases would always make me trip, as I was used to a more 2D perspective from playing the first runner. Moreover, when I tripped, the runner would swim backwards like an octopus, at a constant rate no matter where I was in the level, which was really irratating if I tripped towards the end (compare Runner, where returning to the start took a fixed amount of time, no matter what). The presence of a lot more living things is worse for the feel of the game, though. In the first runner, the living things include huge tunneling worms, fish, clouds with mustaches, and trampolines with eyes. What all of these have in common though is that they are separated from your gameplay. None of them are beneficiaries or detractors to your Herculean run. Your enemies, such as they are, are robots. In Runner2, the first thing you see is a spike-thing sitting in the road. Then, as you go further on, a drunken pickle registers you at a checkpoint. This makes the aesthetic lonliness which the first game had impossible to acheive. End the level, and a sign flips to tell you it's an "Amazing Acheivement!". If you've collected all the gold, you no longer get to go to a fiendishly difficult bonus level, but instead get fired out of a cannon. As the game mechanics were introduced I noticed another thing I didn't like about this sequel, namely, the trigger keys no longer did what they used to. I really enjoyed using A+RTrigger to Jump-kick in the first Runner, but in the second it was not to be. All in all the game comes off as extremely patronizing, with it's hollow achievement system (called 'rewards' for some reason) and its collect all the costumes mentality, which bothers me much more in the face of the sink or swim of the first Runner. It has some promising new mechanics that the first one did not, but they don't necessarily play out. An example is tracing a circle with your right stick, an idea I thought was pretty novel until I realized it had absolutely no impact on the game besides earning extra points. In an effort to enjoy the game more, I switched to the drunken pickle as soon as I possibly could, so that I might be able to enjoy the game for what it was, instead of comparing it to the first runner. A fine idea, though at the character change screen I was briefly greeted by the monstrousity that is CommandgirlVideo. For heavens sake, I believe that collection of black pixel which comprised the protagonist of the first Runner was gender neutral, for that matter, so is the word 'Commander'. Is there any purpose for a second amalgamation of pixels with secondary sexual characteristics other than to alienate half the population from the main protagonist? Do the words 'separate but equal' ring any bells? In any case, I continued playing the game, pretending now that it was the adventures of drunken pickle. I was plesantly releived that noone seemed present at any of the checkpoints, but drunken pickle's extra mode was an all-green rainbow, which should, in any reasonable game, be an oxymoron. I finished off the level, and defeated the boss. But then came a cut scene, featuring CommanderVideo going pointlessly into a whale, even though I'd been playing with drunken pickle the whole time. And then the checkpoints were populated again, by a crab man in a hut. And then I lost interest, and let the game run on to give me Steam Card drops while I wrote this review. So, in conclusion, Runner is better. If you were thinking about playing this game, play Runner. If you've already beaten Runner, go back and do all the challenges, or do it on Perfect mode. If you've already beaten it on perfect mode, then grab your square frames, put them on, and meet me in the cafe down the street, which serves 100% economically sourced coffee-flavored foam, and we can chat about how the first Runner was so much better, before BIT.TRIP went mainstream. Bottom line: Though Runner2 may be better played with a controller, it's better to play the original Runner with that contoller.

Seriously? It's like they took everything they learned from making Dead Island and improved on and polished it til you get this little gem right here. Well I mean the story is still your typical cliche nonsense but the gameplay is so so much better. For one, there are LOADS of active skills you can unlock and use like the ability to throw zombies around, drop kick them, stomp on their faces, slide into them, etc. And due to the way the game works, you can max out all your skill trees with nothing more than a little time and patience. Unlike in Dead Island, the guns are actually useful and the gunplay is much better. Heck, it's good enough that you could just go around guns blazing and not even bother using melee weapons. The downside to that is noise makes fast zombies spawn and swarm your @ss like a bunch of killer bees after disturbing their nest. Also bullets. You cannot make them period. Same applies to any kind of explosives. Grenades, explosive barrels found in the environment naturally and the like will all attract attention, so there's a certain risk/reward balance to using guns and other loud means of killing zombies. Do you go around shooting everything and causing big explosions that'll cause nigh endless waves of fast zombies trying to have your @ss for dinner, or do you go about your business quietly and use melee weapons, unarmed techniques, the environmental traps that aren't super loud and the bow and crossbow? One thing I like about this game is that during missions involving human enemies and room clearing, you can actually stealth them so long as you don't get caught, cause if you do, everyone magically becomes aware of your presence and remain on red alert until you get rid of them all. But yeah, being able to stealth stuff like that in a game like this which really isn't meant for that feels very satisfying. One other thing I kinda disliked, but only applies to The Following dlc, is how the zombies can outrun your car when you only have level 1 parts equipped. You do seem to get way faster when you get offroad suspension, but seriously, a zombie on foot can outrun a flipping car? Seriously come the f*ck on :| It's utter nonsense I tell ya Semi related to that, I hate the way every volatile and viral goes nuts whenever you attack one of them, even if you manage to do so silently. If I one shot a zombo with my crossbow, you'd think that wouldn't set them off. So yeah, that's one of the few things I actually dislike about this game. Another thing I liked about this game is being able to completely stealth any mission involving clearing a building of hostile humans. The game's really not meant for that, but it's still possible nonetheless, so long as you don't get spotted, cause if you do, everyone magically knows you're there and they remain on red alert til you hunt down and finish off every last one of them, cause mgs or sc this ain't. That being said, it's super satisfying to stealth an entire mission in this way in a game that really wasn't meant to be played this way. Course it really helps to have a bow (preferably bozak or ranger, cause the regular bow you get in game is a smelly piece of rancid dogsh*t) or a crossbow and some of the stealhier skills like the takedown from behind. You could just rely on using some melee weapons like an axe or machete, but that's not quite as reliable as the ol vertebral realignment. One of the best changes I feel was getting rid of the workbenches. You do all your crafting in the field and you never have to interrupt the natural flow of gameplay to go find a stupid bench so you can make a million molotovs to throw at zombies. You just put the stuff together on the spot and bam, you got things to use. There is one last thing I feel is kinda really pointless and a bit annoying: repair slots. This really doesn't add much to the game. It just forces you to continually replace your weapons as they wear down. But the thing is, you can also find socketable gems just like in diablo. Thing is, you can't remove them. So if your weapon breaks down permanently, say goodbye to all those upgrade gems. There is one, ONE way to get around this, and that is to do blue shield escort missions. Problem is, they only show up roughly 28% through the game, and even then, it's kind of a crapshoot getting them to appear, and sometimes the guy just flat out f*cking dies while you're trying to make him not die. Then you have to wait literally forever for it to respawn again. That being said, once you have some really great weapons, you won't have to repair it all that much, and there are TONS of ways to kill the zombies without weapons. Like drop kicking or sliding into them and pushing them into a spike trap or onto a car fire. Tossing them off of cliffs and the like. Using the slide kick to lame them all then stomp all their faces into mush. Or using the stun reversal followed up with the stun kill move to instakill them. Or using the vault stun followed up by a stun kill or a takedown from behind. There are @ssloads of ways to kill the zombies without ever necessitating use of any kind of weapon at all. I liked Dead Island but it was a tad basic. This game really fixes that I think. Also parkour. I think more fps should do this and allow you to climb ontop of things you should logically be able to climb onto, none of that can't jump over a waist high barrier nonsense. Seriously, I'm not an 80yo geriatric with a back problem and who requires a cane to get around. It's just flatout ludicrous when you come across something like that in a videogame and it's pretty immersion breaking. Why not just make it look like you cannot pass at all? I think that'd be a lot better. Like Dying Light gets over that problem by putting barbed wire ontop of the fences you can't climb over. That makes really good sense and is a clever way to handle this problem. Also, that last boss fight? Kind of a disappointment. If you're going to do it that way, please make it more satisfying than that? I really really like this game. This is one of the best games I've played in a very long time. While I did get this on sale cause I'm a skinflint, this is well worth full price. Also I highly recommend getting the following with this if for nothing else than the crossbow. That is easily the best weapon in the entire game. Although the semi auto shotgun is still the best for panic situations or just raw firepower. Edit: apparently you can make subsonic bullets for your silenced guns after doing a quest now.

Review: I find this game disappointing on a number of levels, and will probably even remove it from my library at some point. At first I was positively surprised by the colorful graphics and good-looking menu systems. The way planets are displayed, the colors of icons, the graphical design of the UI, I loved it. But frustration set in pretty soon. The tutorial does a really bad job of introducing game elements, being at once boring and much too concise about key aspects of the game. I think I'd rather have read a PDF. Then there's the design of the tech tree. While it looks novel with it's circular layout, I quickly became irritated at the amount of scrolling it requires. The farther into a game, the more techs are found outward from the center. Moving from one extreme of the tech "wheel" to the other requires a lot of work, and as long as you don't know where to find what techs, you'll spend lots of time browsing this huge and inefficient layout. The AI is both cheating and dumb. After a successful war on my part, I managed to reduce an enemy empire to one planet only. They signed a 10-turn peace treaty with me, only to declare war on me 3 turns later because I was considered "a threat". So AI is allowed to break peace treaty, and AI will declare war without any chance of winning? Gotcha. I also dislike the number of turns spent just waiting for things to happen, the tedious micro, the way ship design is never clearly explained, how the hero ability tree overview is a blurry JPG without info, and I dislike the music and ambient sounds. All this lead me to feel empty, alone and bored while playing this game. When it comes to space 4X, I definitely recommend Galactic Civilizations II over this game. It doesn't have as nice graphics but the gameplay, menus, tech tree, game manual as PDF (!), ship design and AI are IMO vastly superior to Endless Space.

Deep Sky Derelicts is a turn-based sci-fi dungeon crawler with RPG elements. It has a distinctive style that reminds me of early works of the french comic artist Enki Bilal, and that's what drew me to it in the first place. The game does not explain things very well. When going to a derelict (a dungeon) you navigate it on a map. This map is made of squares, some of which have symbols (circle, triangle, dash, slash, etc.) on them. But there is no explanation or even a legend of these symbols. Some of them offer a little more information, like "Sandstorm", but it won't tell you that it will damage your team by moving through it. I just had my squad wiped after a 5 hour run by moving through otherwise inconspicuous tiles in the derelict. Damn I hate that. But also in combat, the game doesn't explain things very well. Enemies show what buffs they have, and how many, with beautiful icons. When hovering over them, the game shows you the name of the buff, but not what it does. That makes it really hard to know what's going on. Some debuffs don't seem to have icons. Some cards do a percentage of weapon damage, but they never tell you if it will be based on the ranged or on the melee weapon. If you have a card that deals damage based on the melee damage, but have no melee weapon equipped, that attack will deal almost no damage. But you'll only find out during combat, by seeing the animation done, because the game has no other way of telling you. And then there's the balancing. My latest team was steamrolling levels 1-4, when all of a sudden they hit a brick wall at level 5. They met a group of enemies (red hoods) who magically resisted, evaded or otherwise nullified 75% of all my attacks. I couldn't believe my eyes. Out of the blue. Then there's the matter of having to do quests, but you don't know who for. Or the game tells you who it's for, but you have no idea where to find this person because it doesn't tell you. Or a quest tells you to gather X enemy artifacts, but forgets to tell you in what derelict to find those enemies. Then there's the matter of the paid DLC's. These DLC's contain such basic improvements, and so little of them, that I (and many others) believe they should just have released them as free updates to the base game. Hitboxes are another annoyance. Sometimes it's impossible to hit an enemy if they stand behind a bigger enemy. The game allows attacking the smaller enemy, it's just impossible to click on it. Also, because enemies are animated, an attack sometimes targets a wrong enemy because at the exact time I clicked, an enemy animation switches the hitbox to another enemy. Frustrating. The game also refused to load once, in 9 hours of play. Given all the above, I find that bad form. Deep Sky Derelicts showed some promise in the beginning, but shot itself in the foot by not paying attention to user-friendliness, balancing, and by being greedy. It's a shame because otherwise I love the concept and style very much. 5/10

Review: Domina is a brutal roguelike management game. You are the domina of a bunch of gladiators. It's your job to recruit, gear, heal, feed, train and entertain these guys as best as you can. The goal being to participate in the emperor's championship after one year has passed. After my first two hours, I had ragequit and restarted 5 times. I was ready to give up on this game and demolish my PC, when I read some guides on how to get started and thought to give it another chance. I'm glad I did! Domina is now one of my favorite indie titles ever. I like that it offers many, many unlockables. I love that there are different classes of gladiators, random favor cards, random events and that there are surprises of many kinds. I even like how tough it is to get to the end. Review: XCOM 2 is a turn-based tactical game, in which the earth is overrun by aliens and the player is chosen to lead the human resistance movement, XCOM. XCOM operates from a base which has research facilities and an engineering station which provide many new items, upgrades and tactical advantages. Recruits are managed in the armory, where classes are picked and promotions given once a soldier survives enough missions. Missions are the core of XCOM. They take place on many different maps, each of which offers different tactical challenges and opportunities. At first the aliens encountered on these maps don't present that much of a threat. But as the game progresses, the story unfolds, and XCOM grows stronger, so do the aliens. And depending on the difficulty level, they can obtain almost obscene strength. To the point where you almost have to be a masochist to enjoy it anymore. XCOM 2 is the successor to the massively popular XCOM: Enemy Within from 2013. That game was one of my top 10 games ever. So, how does XCOM 2 compare to the classic EW? Improved: - Graphics: maps are colorful, armor, weapons and item design is definitely more inspired, particle effects more impressive (check my screenshots here https://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561198812088447/screenshots/?appid=268500&sort=newestfirst&browsefilter=myfiles&view=imagewall) - Metagame: base building is more extensive than ever, the research tree is longer, there is more of everything - Music: since the War of the Chosen DLC you can chose from three different soundtracks, and they all work. Impressive! Same-ish - Story: both games convincingly transmit the desperate feeling that the aliens will win, that all is lost - Bradford (but whether that's a good thing...) I disliked: - Most missions are now on a timer. This changes everything. Unless you install a mod that disables the timer (which luckily, there is!) the game no longer gives you the freedom to plan for a perfect strategy - Somehow I am less invested in the story. My brain knows that XCOM 2 improved on every level, but I still enjoy playing XCOM: EW more. EW takes itself a little less serious, it is less dystopian and while the graphics are not as impressive, they sure have more of an outspoken character. - Download size: XCOM 2 with all DLC comes in at a hefty 70 GB! I still can't believe it. Sure, it looks good, but it's far from next gen. - XCOM 2 has bugs that seriously spoil the fun. Indicators that don't reliably preview enemy activation or line of sight, terrain that inexplicably destroys itself, and most aggravating of all: an increasing lag in the final mission. I have to wait three seconds for squad members to react to commands. 7 squad members, times 2 actions, times three seconds means 42 seconds lost to needless waiting every turn! Given the Youtube and Twitch campaigns that I followed online, this is quite a common problem too. All in all, I think XCOM 2 is a solid 7/10 game. It's hard not to recommend it, but there are many games which I find more perfect. I would recommend XCOM 2 to my friends only if they have already played these other games. That said, I think if you are into turn-based tactical games, this title will not disappoint. But you might find (as I did) that you liked Enemy Within a little bit more.

Review: Skyrim is a huge open fantasy world that allows you to role play as a Mage, Warrior or Thief, or any combination of these classes. Mods provide bug fixes, better graphics, improved balancing, new content, or even complete overhauls, adding even more replayability to this already massive game. Absolutely recommended.

Review: I like the base mechanics of the game. It reminds me of tabletop card games and I like that. It has a concise set of rules, a clear and user-friendly icon system, and straight-forward gameplay mechanisms that are easy to grasp but hard to master. If the game gets everything right, then why do I not recommend it? One reason is the endless grind. I have about 16 hours on the game and still haven't unlocked most of the available cards. I don't understand why I would have to grind through the game using the same cards and tactics time and time again, while there's a wealth of other options available in game. The game is nice, but not so nice that I'm willing to waste 100 hours just to unlock the coolest stuff. But my most pressing reason for disliking this game is the in-game advertisements. Every few games, there would be a nag screen begging me to pay attention to the other games of the developer, or to write a review. It doesn't take much to click those screens away but I'm aggravated by the idea. I already gave you my money. Now leave me alone so I can get on and play the game! For these two reasons, I uninstalled and will probably remove the game from my library at some point in time.
